fields.description:
There must be a way to export the information shown in the Reviews tab to an excel file, similar to the excel export in the Jira issue navigator. 

The point is *not* to export all the review data (e.g. comments). That may be a good idea, but would be a *separate* feature request. Just follow the model of the Jira issue navigator!
fields.summary: Implement excel export for crucible review metadata.

fields.description:
I often (as author or as reviewer) want to check what revisions are present in review.
Currently only way is clicking every file in review and watching the red bar with revision numbers above diff content.
That's very time consuming and nearly impossible for larger reviews.

One option would be displaying this information in file tree on the left.
Maybe even better would be information like: this review contains all files from changesets 1,5,7.
For revisions containing only some files from changeset some combination of options above could be used.
fields.summary: Unable to see all changsets in review

fields.description:
This is related to CRUC-2998.  Where CRUC-2998 focuses only on iterative pre-commit reviews, this feature would allow iteration of the review to continue with a post-commit changeset.

Something that I've run into a few times  is that it is not uncommon for us that a review begins as pre-commit but we would really like to iterate on it post commit. This lets those potentially ugly changes start off a bit safer (pre-commit review) but then once they've had a chance for at least a first pass or two of changes be committed and reviewed with the benefits of a regular iterative review.
fields.summary: Iterative review: pre-commit transition to post-commit

fields.description: If new revisions are added half-way a review, all (even unread files) will only show the added revisions by default. Thus, opening an unread file will not show the complete changeset included in the review. The range of revisions can be expanded to include all revisions, but this has to be done for every file and can be easily overlooked.
fields.summary: "new since last read" view fails when half-way new revisions are added to a review

fields.description:
given that a feature we want to add very soon (iterative patch reviews) will very likely require either anchored or full patch reviews, it would be good to have the script include full context.

all but p4 are easy.

p4 will likely require us to get the 2 versions of the file and diff them ourselves - probably not a big deal given that we're already doing it for added / removed files
fields.summary: review CLI  should include full context

This exception is caught, so the impact is limited to the loss of Review Join Activity Items in that request.

h4. Workaround
# Run the following query - replace the {{review_ID}} with value found in the stack after {{review-join}}:
{code:sql}SELECT * FROM CRU_LOGITEM WHERE CRU_REVIEW_ID=<review_ID> ORDER BY CRU_CREATE_DATE;{code} E.g. the value in stack above is 9943 from {{reviewer-join:9943}}: {code:sql}SELECT * FROM CRU_LOGITEM WHERE CRU_REVIEW_ID=9943 ORDER BY CRU_CREATE_DATE;{code}
# Identify rows with the same value in the {{CRU_CREATE_DATE}} that have the same {{CRU_REVIEW_ID}}.
# Stop Crucible.
# Backup the database.
# Add one second to all of the entries ({{CRU_LOGITEM_ID}}) that you identified in step #2, e.g. {code:sql}update CRU_LOGITEM set CRU_CREATE_DATE=CRU_CREATE_DATE+1000 where CRU_LOGITEM_ID=4578 and CRU_REVIEW_ID=219;{code}.
# Start Crucible.

fields.description:
Some of our projects are working with patch queues in Mercurial:

* There is a "base" repo containing normal source files (e.g. from an open source community).
* There is a related "patch" repo containing patchs of the sources in the base repo.
* There is _no_ repo containg changesets resulting from applying the patches to the base files.

This is a standard structure in Mercurial and well supported.

So now we come to a review and the problem is that the reviewer sees only changesets in the patch repo, which do not contain enough context.

The situation is somewhat similar to the "pre-commit" feature that Crucible already supports. We tried to figure out a way to shoehorn our problem into this feature, but it doesn't work. The crucial problem is the hash of the patch ("diff -r"), which depends on all previous applied patches. Taken apart from them, it does not work when reviewing only a single patch from the middle of the queue.

What is needed here is some logic in the review that understands how a patch queue functions. We see the following use case supported:

# The review is created from Jira for one or more changesets in the patch repo.
# As in the case for a pre-commit review, the user should be able to choose an "anchor" changeset in the base repo. Crucible applies the patch if possible; if not, it informs the user that the anchor is not patchable.
# The files in the base repo that are updated by the application of the patches are displayed to the reviewer as reviewable files and his comments are associated with these files for the selected anchor.
# The user may choose different anchors during the review, with the patches delivering different results in the base repo. *The comments are not lost when the user switches anchors.*

We won't try to specify more here. Suffice it to say, the Atlassian developers should just try to use the patch queue feature of Mercurial and then implement a good way of reviewing patches in Crucible. :)
fields.summary: Crucible patch queue review feature needed.

fields.description:
Customer suggested following improvements when creating new crucible review:
{quote}
It makes more sense if the "Author and Moderator of the created Review" 
is the person who requests the review (the reporter of the jira issue 
who clicks on "request review code"). The person who is assigned the 
review is then added as a reviewer to the review, so in their dashboard, 
the reviewer participant would see a review appear in their "To Review" 
filter. Ideally once the assignee (reviewer) or reporter 
(author/moderator) resolves the "In Review" jira ticket, the crucible 
ticket is automatically summarized. If the author/moderator closes and 
summarizes the crucible ticket, it should also close the jira ticket as 
"fixed and reviewed". That way there is a tight relationship between 
the jira issue and crucible review, and the crucible and jira roles are 
aligned. Make sense?

If I were to include the field additional assignees to the workflow 
screen, could you also add these as additional reviewers to the crucible 
ticket?

Thanks!
{quote}
fields.summary: Improvements in workflow when creating crucible review

Please change it back to 'Let allowed review participants join a review' (for review edit detail dialog) or 'By default, let allowed review participants join a review' (project setting)

fields.description:
If a user is not authenticated to the Remote JIRA Server when linking a JIRA issue key to a Crucible Review, the following message is displayed in the UI:

!CR-FE-7160 2013-03-15 12-58-17.jpg!

And the following appears in the logs

{code}
2013-03-14 20:56:35,913 DEBUG [IncrementalPinger3 Critter] fisheye LoggingProcessMonitor-onBeforeStart - Starting process: /usr/bin/git show-ref -d --tags 
2013-03-14 20:56:35,916 DEBUG [qtp32565619-74196 ] fisheye JiraIssueServiceImpl-logException - Error retrieving issue 'JRADEV-13927' from JIRA server at https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/JRADEV-13927
com.atlassian.crucible.spi.services.NotPermittedException: com.atlassian.jira.rpc.exception.RemoteAuthenticationException: User not authenticated yet, or session timed out.
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.soap.JiraUALSoapInvoker.invokeOperation(JiraUALSoapInvoker.java:42)
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.soap.AbstractJiraSoapInvoker.invoke(AbstractJiraSoapInvoker.java:31)
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.JiraServerImpl.invoke(JiraServerImpl.java:246)
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.JiraServerImpl.getIssue(JiraServerImpl.java:251)
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.issue.JiraIssueServiceImpl.retrieveJiraIssue(JiraIssueServiceImpl.java:169)
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.issue.JiraIssueServiceImpl.getJiraIssue(JiraIssueServiceImpl.java:97)
        at com.atlassian.crucible.actions.create.LinkReviewToJiraAjaxAction.linkJiraKey(LinkReviewToJiraAjaxAction.java:142)
        at com.atlassian.crucible.actions.create.LinkReviewToJiraAjaxAction.execute(LinkReviewToJiraAjaxAction.java:106)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)

{code}

The issue key does exist, however at another JIRA instance: JDOG.
There are a few problems here:

# We seem to only report one of the jira instances in the UI, and it is wrong - Ecosystem
# We don't provide a link to that instance to allow an end user to Authenticate
# We tell the end user to go looking through the logs, when what they have is a simple authentication issue which can all be sorted in the browser.


I would like to see the following improvements made:
* we detect authentication errors when trying to link to a JIRA server, from other errors.
* we display all JIRA servers which were tried, and could not authenticate with - not just the first one.
* the error messages should provide hrefs to the login pages for those failed JIRA servers
fields.summary: Better handling of Authentication Errors when manually linking a Review to a JIRA Issue

fields.description:
If crucible is configured with many Projects, and Permission Schemes, then when loading the list of projects a particular user has permission to create reviews in, Crucible can perform many many separate database queries.

This can cause extreme slowness during the review creation process, especially page load times of pages containing a list of projects. e.g. Edit Details.

The slowness is made worse when the database server is not on the same network or machine as the Crucible instance, due to the chattiness of Crucible to the SQL Database.
fields.summary: Optimize number of database queries for Crucible instances with Many Projects and Permission Schemes

fields.description:

fields.summary: Crucible's Changeset Review Coverage gadget in Jira shouldn't include SVN copy

fields.description:
As a user, I want to only select reviews for a specific time span via REST.

This is currently not possible using REST, however the underlying code supports it.

What is to do:

# add 2 new query parameters to the /filter/details REST API
## fromDate, toDate - both long millis since epoch
# add a fromDate/toDate to the ReviewFilterDef
# Pass these values to the CrucibleReviewQueryBuilder in getReviewIdsAsRolesInStates, if these values are set

Then only reviews between those dates will be returned.
Leaving off a toDate will search all reviews up to now.
Leaving off a fromDate will search all reviews up to toDate.

Once this is done, tell [~mark@atlassian.com] so he can update his Crucible Reviews Script to use these parameters.
fields.summary: Allow /filter/details to include a date range filter

fields.description:
We have found that the Crucible changesets are sorted by commit creation time, not modification time. Can this be made to be configurable?

Here's an example of a use case. We are using Git.

1. Developer starts working on some feature, let's say on time T, and makes some commits
2. A couple days later at time T+N he merges it to "dev" and wants it code-reviewed. In the meantime he might have rebased his feature branch several times (thus changing the modification time as well)
3. The resultant "Add Content to Review" lightbox sorts the commits by creation time (time T) rather than the modification time, which means the commits to be reviewed appear far down the list.
fields.summary: Allow Crucible changesets to be sorted by modification time, not creation time

This issue is deriving from https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6312.

One customer mentioned that because Crucible is based on diffs reviews than it is possible to miss some lines of code for an file that has been added and then modified.

In order to help identify those cases we could visually indicate that a file has been added in the revision selector.

*To be a satisfactory fix, the default result seen by a reviewer when they first visit a review must tell the reviewer that the file has been added in this review, and must show them the full contents of the file without them needing to adjust any controls.*
fields.summary: Indicate in the revision selector when a revision has been added

fields.description:
Apparently our DB creation/upgrade scripts generated by Hibernate create duplicate indexes for unique columns where the index name was provided.
For example for User entity defined with property:
{code:xml}
        <property name="username" column="cru_user_name" type="string" length="255" not-null="true" unique="true" index="idx_user_name"/>
{code}

MySQL schema is:
{code}
show create table cru_user;
cru_user | CREATE TABLE `cru_user` (
  `cru_user_id` int(11) NOT NULL,
  `cru_user_name` varchar(255) collate utf8_bin NOT NULL,
...
  PRIMARY KEY  (`cru_user_id`),
  UNIQUE KEY `cru_user_name` (`cru_user_name`),
  KEY `idx_user_name` (`cru_user_name`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 COLLATE=utf8_bin

show indexes from cru_user;
+----------+------------+---------------+--------------+---------------+-----------+-------------+----------+--------+------+------------+---------+
| Table    | Non_unique | Key_name      | Seq_in_index | Column_name   | Collation | Cardinality | Sub_part | Packed | Null | Index_type | Comment |
+----------+------------+---------------+--------------+---------------+-----------+-------------+----------+--------+------+------------+---------+
| cru_user |          0 | PRIMARY       |            1 | cru_user_id   | A         |           1 |     NULL | NULL   |      | BTREE      |         |
| cru_user |          0 | cru_user_name |            1 | cru_user_name | A         |           1 |     NULL | NULL   |      | BTREE      |         |
| cru_user |          1 | idx_user_name |            1 | cru_user_name | A         |           1 |     NULL | NULL   |      | BTREE      |         |
+----------+------------+---------------+--------------+---------------+-----------+-------------+----------+--------+------+------------+---------+
3 rows in set (0.00 sec)
{code}

note there are two keys defined on the same cru_user_name column.
It's not a big issue but having two indexes means increased disk usage and higher cost of DML operations, as each insert/update for this column would have to update two indexes instead of one.

Same issue is with indexes cru_perm_scheme.name column.

Easy fix would be to stop using named indexes for this property and drop duplicated indexes.  Issue may apply to other to MySQL databases as well.
fields.summary: Duplicate indexes on some unique columns in MySQL

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Create a review and linked to a JIRA issue
# Change a Status name in JIRA for example: 'In Progress' -> 'Starting'
# Close the review and transition the linked issue to the renamed status
# The retrieved JIRA issue status after transitioned is 'In Progress'
# Restarting Crucible fix the problem
fields.summary: Crucible does not retrive the latest JIRA issue status name

fields.description:
We're doing crucible post-commit reviews, and reviews are added via REST API (json).
For one specific review, we've found that the attached changeset do not display any of the changes made in the corresponding revision in the repository.
Please see the attached image reviewCableAnalogAutoSearchDialog.jpg for CableAnalogAutoSearchDialog.hpp's file contents in the review. 

But the repository's (svn) revision 85584's changeset contents are attached as reposCableAnalogAutoSearchDialog.diff and is very different from the review's contents !?
fields.summary: Review file contents do not match with the repository changes.

fields.description:
You can set your permission scheme to allow *allLoggedInUsers* to be able to comment on reviews.

Currently though, they will not receive emails for comments on the review, even if they are direct replies.

We should:
* send notifications to all users in the parent comment stack, even if they are not participants in the review
* change the agile permission scheme to allow all logged in users to comment on reviews
fields.summary: Send notifications for replies to comments even if the user is not in the review

fields.description:
Handling of new files in Crucible can be quite unclear to reviewers. Two scenarios:

*1 - Reviewing a change set with a new file*
A file is added and the change set is added to a review. The only pointer to know a file is new is the 'Added' arrow next to the file name. The diff is not completely green (it is in Fisheye, which seems quite inconsistent to me). See scenario1.png.

*2 - Reviewing two change sets with a new file and a change to this file*
See scenario2a.png, scenario2b.png and scenario2c.png. 

In change set c311802 the file is added, in change set 247ed42 a change is made to the same file. By default, the state of the file in change set 247ed42 is shown (scenario2a.png). The arrow next to the file name states something has been changed, but this cannot be distilled from the diff (no changes are shown). It is also not clear that the actual file is a new file, added in revision c311802.

When viewing the changes between the two change sets, it becomes clear that a line has been removed (scenario2b.png). It is still unclear that the file is a new file that needs reviewing.

When viewing only change set c311802, the situation is equal to scenario 1 (scenario2c.png)

Overall, it is very hard for a reviewer to figure out that a file is actually new and needs reviewing. As a consequence, files can stay unreviewed.
fields.summary: Improve displaying of new files in diff

fields.description: If the file name is too long, the 'View' dropdown is missing and 'Add a file comment. Click on source lines to add an inline comment.' and/or the top most file content is hidden
fields.summary: File path bar overlays file content for long file names in review

fields.description:
In the screenshots below, the 2nd and 4th of 4 draft comments are deleted by Crucible when posting all drafts.

Unfortunately, I was not as lucky when encountering this bug in a real review and all but one of ~40 comments were deleted.

I have tried to reproduce several times with different reviews, and at least 50% of the draft comments have been deleted in each trial.

The cause is explained in [this comment|#comment-705779].

h3. Workaround
Restrain from clicking "Complete anyway" button in the warning dialog if you want to publish all drafts.  Click "Post drafts" link instead, await counters in the file tree browser on the left hand side to update with.   Cancel dialog, click the "Complete" action again, repeat again if any draft comments are found.
fields.summary: Post drafts link when completing a review deletes most or all of the draft comments

fields.description:

* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Migrating+to+SQL+Server
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Migrating+to+SQL+Server

Is it the same as JIRA: "This database user should not be the database owner, but should be in the db_owner role."
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA052/Connecting+JIRA+to+SQL+Server+2005

fields.description: The create button should be disabled until the dialog has finished loading currently you can click create before most of the fields have been rendered (if you're quick)
fields.summary: IIC: you can click create before the inline issue creation dialog has finished loading

fields.description:
Plugin makes unneeded (and incorrect) AJAX requests due to plugin javascript being included on all pages.  For example.  the add revisions page has a review object but does not know the review ID in the javascript model, so it requests linked issue details for an undefined review id.

!Screen Shot 2013-01-14 at 10.21.22 AM.png!

These requests only need to be made on the review page.  We should either be not including the IIC javascript in other pages, or doing a check in the IIC JS that the page being viewed is the review page before making the request.
fields.summary: IIC Plugin makes unneeded AJAX requests on pages other than the review page

fields.description:
Using 'click' as 'add comment is HIGHLY annoying and non-standard.  Why that choice??

This causes two SERIOUS usability issues:

a) This means I can not scroll through the code without going to my mouse to go over to the scrollbar.  I am a keyboardist: this just impacted my speed/productivity.

b) I can not copy code from the source. this is a true showstopper.

 Yes, I tried the following:

          alt Hold down then click and drag to select source line contents.

What that does?  It ends up selecting lots of extraneous text, and I cannot control it.

Why was the default browser behaviour changed for cut and paste and scroll??? That's a serious negative usability choice.

Please inform how to revert the "click to add comment" so I can get normal click back.  After all it looks like 'c' is already there for 'add comment', so click is an extra.  

Easy: add user option to disable 'click to comment'. That will resolve this bug.  

Until then I am one very unhappy camper, i have wasted a lot of time with this, more than the amount of time actually working in the tool.


thanks.
fields.summary: Using 'click' as 'add comment subverts browser usability and is essentially showstopper; need user option to revert to normal browser usage
Bulk review operations (e.g. close)
